column2: marie0156, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

column2: revKathie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: Leelee, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have arthritis, bursitus, and fibromayalsia. Found that the patches have worked really well for me. I am however really dissapointed with the cash pay price. Prescription for 60 patches is $425 here in Florida. But, how do you put a price on pain relief that is non-narcotic? Narcotic pain meds only lead to more pain meds and more pain. Take it from one who has been there and has recovered from 5 years of dependance. Flector patches have helped me get off those kind of meds. If King Pharmicuticals and the other company that distributes these patches is reading this, you would sell much more of the patches if you would lower the price and get the FDA approval for use on the conditions that most doctors are prescribing them for!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Used patch for arthritic, bursitis and fibromyalgia in both hips, cut one in half to put on each side, changed them every 12 hours, stayed on well and worked. After 15 days I am covered in itchy hives and have been given an inhaler to help stop the constant coughing I have developed. Now trying Singular to get rid of the hives. With the added stress of this, pain is now worse then before and I itch like crazy. Everyday I wake up to see what part of my body has the hives now, hope it ends soon, it's been 5 days so far and yes I quit the patch when this started.

column2: Maria Filos, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am using the Flector Patch on my knee after just having knee replacement. However, I have noticed from the knee down I have broken out in a  rash

column2: JR, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have long-term, major back issues and I've had multiple surgeries/fusions for my lower back. For the past several years I've had significant constant pain in my spine just below the shoulder blades. The pain managment doctor prescribed these patches to help alleviate the pain. Unfortunately, they have no effect on my pain so I still hurt like heck. The only think that seems to work for me is highest allowable dose of slow release morphine sulfate 3 x day, and the highest allowable dose of percocet 3 x a day along with ice. For me, these patches are a complete waste of time and money and royal pain to put on my back. As my back hurts, the contortions necessary to put this on my back are unbelievable and then the patch does not stick well so I'm constantly having to press it back down. I'd recommend saving your money and the annoyance and do NOT accept a prescription for the patches.

column2: Honest Abe, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am really on the fence with these patches.  First off, it looks like a LOT of people are in the same boat as I am- my insurance didn't cover them and a 15-day supply (30 patches) cost almost $200!!!!Secondly, they only work for minor sprains and aches, which is not what I have and my dr. is well aware.  My dr. is a pain management dr. and he and I talked about Lidoderm patches and How I had used them in the past with good results...and that I was sketchy about these patches because of their interactions with coumadin (blood thinner) and possible GI bleeding. Doesn't matter, I guess.I get 'em anyways, and now, I have no Dr. because I know the pain management Dr. wants to try everything under the sun before entitling me to what works.  I can't afford 2 monthly RX's @ over $350 just so he can "step me up" slowly.  But I digress.  I still keep some of these patches around for muscle aches, they seem to work OK.  Only thing about (all) patches- they just don't hang well with me and my back :)

column2: AC joint arthitis, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: My insurance refuses to pay for this medication after the first fill. It has to be pre approved for just minor strains, sprains and bruising. Per the FDA approval use. I have been able to avoid surgery by using them when I have a flare up. My pain management doctor prescribed them for that pain the next time I saw him. Thank goodness I had enough left over for a while. It is a shame that insurance compainies make you jump through hoops like this.  This medication works wonders for AC joint arthitis.

column2: sadlittlesis, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: after shoulder arthroscopy flector patch pre-scribed for my sister, apparently with no reguard to who should not be taking this patch,at 61 after 2 months on this she had a massive gastrointestinal bleed and died in my living room.I wish I had researched this drug from the start instead of just trusting her Surgeon,would never give her medication that dangerous,fatal I was so wrong, Linda so trusting neither of us questioned his choice of medication then,now everyday I do,and wish I had then.I can't get over HOW and why such a senseless horrific way to die over a little patch that was suppose to help.stick with the old common pain and anti-inflammatory medicine, new is not better.I miss you so much Linda,everyday I wish I had asked more questions,gotten more info,cause I truly believe you'd still be here with me....

column2: etigress_62@yahoo.com, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

column2: ks1988, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: worked extremely well.

column2: sue, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: the flector patch has been a miracle for me! i've had severe SI inflammation, dysfunction, and pain for 10 years. NSAIDs work but i can not take them due to edema and gastritis. wearing ice 24/7 was becoming impractical. getting cortisone injections every 6 months was not something i wanted to do. so, i came up with the idea to try the flector patch over the SI. i wear one 24/7, change it every 12 hours. it took a few days for my SI inflammation and pain and looseness to go away, but since then its essentially gone, except when i go without it to see if i really need it. within a few hours, it is clear that the flector patch is necessary. and i've had absolutely no side effects from it in the 6 months i've been on it, no gastritis, no edema, no skin irritation. it does take a day or so to take full effect, but if you keep using it and leave it on and change it every 12 hours, its miraculous in its effectiveness. i have an overall inflammatory arthritis as well, but the SI joint was the main thing that made living impossible. now its no longer a problem. i also sometimes have really bad flares in my rhomboid area of my upper back. that is also disabling. when it hits, i can not sleep, can not sit, and the pain causes the physical symptoms of a panic attack: gastritis and pounding heart. in desperation, i cut my flector patch in half, put half over my SI joint and put the other half over the left rhomboid area. it took a few hours, but what a difference! last year, i was out of work for 6 months while trying to heal the injury. this time i think i might actually be able to nip it in the bud before it snowballs out of control thanks to the flector patch. and if i pat it on well, and wear clothing over it, it does stick just fine. though taping is always another option.the flector patch has changed my life for the better! i was looking at disability. now i can live my life. i also use a topical triple nsaid KIP gel for other occasional spots like the neck.

column2: lf57, 45-54 Male  (Patient)
column9: I had a compression fracture of my pelvis rearing some of the ligaments attached to my spine. About 2 months after surgery my lower back was the only residual pain. I don't want anymore narcotic pain medicine so the doctor gave me the patches and they worked. I was truly amazed

column2: Leave01, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was given the patch by my Dr for fybromialsia pain. I have muscle spasms that made me feel like a knife was stabbing thru my back into my lung.  I used one for 12hrs and it worked great! By 11PM I was so cold my teeth where chattering, I was shaking and shivering under the covers and my husband said it was HOT in the house. I shook for 2hrs and felt hung over the next day. Severe nausea and migraine headache. It was like severe withdrawal symptoms. I have discontinued using the patch.

column2: T man, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month

column2: drsean, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: As a pain management physician I was excited when this patch first became available, especially with the problems with the Cox II's and potential side effects of all other anti-inflamatories.My experience with this medication has been somewhat dissapointing and perhaps that is because many of my patients have a tendency to compare expectations of their meds with those of narcotic analgesics. (Some even believe they are being given Fentanyl patches I believe).Overall, proper expectations of this med as well as utilization techniques, coupled with the apparent lower degree of side effects based upon the cutaneous delivery method, make this med a good option for some.My advice is first to apply the patch according to directions.Next, I advise additional use of a good skin adhesive tape, as the patches simply do not adhere well to many persons and/or body regions.Finally, I would advise to patience in order to allow the drug to work. A, "One patch trial", simply does not allow time for an adequate responce. The anti-inflamatory process takes time and by giving the patches adequate time, some patients are pleasantly surprised by their benefit.So, in summary, I believe the Flector Patch to be a product that can indeed be helpful for some. Do not expect a narcotic like responce. Apply the patches as directed. Utilize addition skin adhesive tape. Change the patches evey 12 hours and properly dispose of them. Make sure to reseal the patches and do not use expired patches. Finally, be patient. Perform supplemental exercises (Ask you doctor, chiropractor or physical therapist if appropriate and what exercises to do). Limited exacerbating activities and you may find the patches to be helpful.

column2: IROC L69, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was thrown from a motorcycle onto my back six months ago. After all the therapy and rehab I still have severe lower back pain. I cut my patches in half and apply directly over the area giving me pain. This medication is a god send. My first day of use was my first pain free day in six months. So far no side affects to speak of. I do take nexium for an over acid stomach condition I have had since 12 years of age. For me the Flector patch is a miracle healer.

column2: gamount, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have syringiomylia, a small bubble in my spinal cord that causes spurious nerve pain. He suggested I shave an area to apply the patch... My solution was a place on my butt! I now wear boxers at night and the patch stays put and doesn't roll off as I sleep. It has really helped with my sleep and pain but seems to interfere with my libido. Anybody else noticed this symptom?
